conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on blocks A and B; block A is about to slip and block B is about to slide down.
Let m_A and m_B be the masses of blocks A and B, respectively.
Block B is pushed by a horizontal force and is in close contact with block A.
Gravity on block B is m_Bg downward.
Friction between A and B is f = μ_1 F_N upward.
Since block B is about to slide down, f = m_Bg, so μ_1 F_N = m_Bg.
Horizontal force F is applied to block A to the left.
Friction between A and ground is f' = μ_2 (m_A + m_B)g to the right.
Since block A is about to slip, f' = F, so F = μ_2 (m_A + m_B)g.
The horizontal force F is also the normal force F_N acting on block B.
From the equation for block B, μ_1 F = m_Bg.
Substitute F = μ_2 (m_A + m_B)g into the block B equation.
μ_1 (μ_2 (m_A + m_B)g) = m_Bg simplifies to μ_1 μ_2 (m_A + m_B) = m_B.
Rearrange the equation to solve for the mass ratio m_A/m_B.
Divide everything by m_B to get μ_1 μ_2 m_A/m_B + μ_1 μ_2 = 1.
Isolate m_A/m_B to find m_A/m_B = (1 - μ_1 μ_2)/(μ_1 μ_2).
The mass ratio of A to B is (1 - μ_1 μ_2)/(μ_1 μ_2).
